gestures.plaintext: It is said by the invidi-ous Gibbon that while the Vatican has been so disfigured that were the Apostles to revisit it they would not know it, the lofty dome of St Sophia retains the representation of the humble tabernacle of Medina. And that while chistian commentaries have so disfigured the text as wd oblige their original authors to study thier own writings, the koran remains the infallible code of religious & civil legislation. In this blending of sacred & civvil interests it is true Gibbon finds the cause of the permancy of mohammedan ism.

gestures.plaintext: If there is any possible or established connction between means & ends—asking & finding, I’ll seek that the dark cloud of ignorance be removed in a measure consistent with my condition & my hopes as a believr in a divine relation & agency. Edwards speaking of these connections says. “The supposed connetion betwen antecedents & consequ ents let it be ever so sure & nessecay does not does not prove that it is in vain for a man to attempt to open, his eyes—his aiming—& the use of means being the effect of his will does not breake the connection nor hinder the success.” May not the free will of a moral Agent be a link in the chain of events each of which is ordered by God—and yet the free-dom not the less than if any temporey motive—or accident had induced the will to act. In short, it seems that the will of a being with a moral capasity is nothing more than an instru-ment of the divine govt of the most misterious kind in living to issue the most stupendous schemes according to the Edwards’ system.

            <lb/>Omnipotent Power to overrule the chaos of human affairs,
            <lb/>after they have taken what may be called a <hi rend="underline()">natural</hi>
            cou<supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">rse.</supplied>
               </itg>
gestures.plaintext: What Wollaston quotes from Plut. that the immortality &c and the doctrine of Pro. stands &c does not appear solid, unless by immortality be intended future existence— Admit this, or that the soul is na-turally immortal—and tho’ it argues strongly a superintending Govoner—yet does not prove it— It may enter into the design of a moral govt of free agents that their actions should take their own course in general—that it is the province of Omnipotent Power to overrule the chaos of human affairs, after they have taken what may be called a natural course.

                  <lb/>formed the whole <subst><seg read=" " type="subst" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><del read="of" type="subst" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="subst" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><add hand="#MME">plan</add><seg read=" " type="subst" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></subst> of the creation and redemption
          <lb/>from a perfect view of all it’s consequences; to such a
          <lb/>believer, whose views are thus extended—a final res<seg read="- " type="shy-part" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><lb break="no"/>toration becomes a kind of intuition. In the native
          <lb/>depravity of human, fallen nature, in its connection

                  <itg type="reference" cert="high" source="b:IT50001" xml:id="f04i001"> <hi rend="underline()">all are</hi>
                  <lb/>

                  </ab><lb/>
                  <ab type="pbGroup" subtype="add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"><mw type="pageNum" rend="align(left) encircled" xml:id="tn.sec.427a" read="6" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/>
                  </ab><lb/>they are, nor what they are.</itg>
gestures.plaintext: degree of liberty and freedom of will (which does not appear philosophical or scriptural to the calvinistic Inquirier) that I should look for the belief, the sublime and godlike belief that human misery will find an universal remedy. To him, who views every man as unconnected with a federal head—born innocent in the most pofit sense—free in the most perfect manner, the scheme of eternal anguish may be more consistent with the manifest attributes of God and the nature of things. But to the consistent Calvinist, who believes in a God without succession of ideas—to whom the future of every possible existence was always present—always and nessecarily connected with His will and agency—who from a formed the whole plan of the creation and redemption from a perfect view of all it’s consequences; to such a believer, whose views are thus extended—a final restoration becomes a kind of intuition. In the native depravity of human, fallen nature, in its connection with a first reperesentative, and it’s misterious and aggrandising relation to a Second by whom came all are made alive—in the nessisity of a foreign and divine agency to conversion, are found supports of the restoration from scripture of an unanswerable nature, without adverting to those numerous select passages which support this belief— And in truth, I know not where they are, nor what they are.

gestures.plaintext: This 7th lect abounds with illustrations & lights on the econymy of Provedence of lasting value adorned by an eloquence w’h must rivet attention. If the conservitive disputes the value of machinery and the moral power of the best Artist, his acrimony will be softened. If he still recurs to the sad facts of true and ever honored genius like Dante Columbus and numbers of suffering talents (even the xian Young who meanly wished the notice of a Queen), the favor of pub-lick & its oracles were nessceary to aid his their powers & brighten their declening life. How many amiable Keates have actually died? And it will always be a doubt, with the obscure & ignorant, whether the arts & science itself have aided made the most stronge & martyr spirits to the cross & to the publick welfare? There are problemns of an exclusive religious nature w’h lie at the basis of human existence w’h even this pow-erfull writer as yet has not solved & probably never can be in this life by the profoundest & widest phi-losophy, but w’h xianity alone remidies by a faith w’h is supernatural. More than faith—the certainty of its truths coeval with & developing the intuiteons of the heart. Here is the “certitude,” w’h even Morell cannot improve. It is content with what is nessecarily mysterious as it is an inevitable condition of a being like man, and often adds to the charms of his future prospects in the worlds of knowledge and indescrible joy of studying the Infinite! Here lies the glorious effect of this lecture, when by a few facts of the wonders of that God gift by w’h the idea of the powers of the Creator were bro’t to veiw in His works! Then the most imprisoned & limited soul finds an ark of safty in this incompre-hensible and boundless Being thro the medium of His Son! And mysteries & a world of complicated ills all vanish and the restoration of the time worn race gives a consolation w’h no delighfell prospects of its “progress” here can equal. More more lectures!

gestures.plaintext: “The great spheres to w’h our intu-itions are directed are those of the beautifull the good and true, & corresponding to these are three classes of emotion aesthetical, the moral and those hitherto un-named heavings of the spirit, when it contemplates the awfull majesty and immensity of Being—pure eternal Being”!

Well there

gestures.plaintext: But this hour I pass them, & all his cool calatons to the Absolute the nessecary glorious first Cause. There lives the eternal and I in Him by nessesity of creation. Halleluia. A moment & comes the sins weakneses & disgraces w’h have kept me penitent these tedious times of ill health. Well there comes the Cross, who tho possibly the agent & priest of worlds before ours, yet died after sufferings, from w’h he shrunk, to fill the awfull chasm w’h sin had made between God & man, and to individual misery a safty & assurance.

               <seg xml:id="an95.413">I have been to lecture tonight—<rs ref="mp:PP1">poor
                     Preacher</rs> but my <lb/>ardor is not to be cooled.</seg>

                  <hi rend="underline()">What can I render!</hi>

gestures.plaintext: How inrapturing the sight of the Heavens—exalt the sentiment— by remembering the voice of inspiration these shall perish —shall wax old as a garment as a vesture shalt thou fold them! I have been to lecture tonight—poor Preacher but my ardor is not to be cooled. What can I render! I felt worldly too!

gestures.plaintext: Day of that sort of pleasure w’h I fear—prevented zeal penitence & knowledge—relaxed—vain tho’ts insued— Cannot accuse myself of indolence in deed—felt the sweet influence of secret hope, joy & charity. But in gaining the habit of meditation this eve I strove to add numbers of ages to my existence— How then frivolous does all injoyt appear on this earth—how dangerous—sd any thing be ommitted!!!! how extensive is the effect of one idea on the principal of association —how extensive the association in the world of ideas—after millions of years, when on the verge of a new existence (for such is the nature of created existences to be forever new to life) on entering new scenes—untried & full of hope then to feel the full effect of some long forgotten habit—!! the remotest posibility of such consequences (& such as we find here in this imperfect sketch of God’s moral govt ) sd arouse a never ceasing anxiety! It is said that the desire of immort is universal—the desire of continued existence is—but when I contemplate endless being I shudder & am confounded—if it be an n appetite, one object incomprehensible— A late Philos (Fellows) observes among many other errors that the hope & expectation of immort does not prove it. “for we are so constituted organised that we could not pass thro’ life, in our circumstances without the sentiment, since the untutored Savage feels it more acutely than the Phi.” Query. Is there any appetite thro’out our organisation to w’h some object is not adapted? I acknowledge, it is from our organisation the sentiment arises—that it is an inmate of the soul & not a deduction of reason I allow, & the case of Savage proves it to be such. I can find no argument for a future existence from reason, unless it be the reason of a Deist.— —hence the nessisity of a revelation—for that of a Deist is feeble, & insuficient (alone) for the purposes of morality. The crude expectation w’h has dwelt univirsally in the mind of man, tho’ it does not prove to a demonstration the truth of a future somthing, yet furnishes an argument irrestistable to contrary reason, and supports the internal evidences of revelation. Still what I call the desire of immot is only a desire of continued consciousness— As a proof of endless being it seems we may rank that novelty w’h perpetually attends life—on the borders of the graee the hoary sage looks forward with an invarible elasticity of mind.— or hope

gestures.plaintext: for if we allow that those laws were origenally pasd by a moral Governor, they are from the beginning adapted to moral purposes, those parts therefor in the moral system w’h appear deviations from what we call general laws of nature & ways of Provi may be in fact only a part of them tho’ the sight is too dim to see their connection. These tho’ts readily reconcile the notion of prescience & an overruling Provi. for in fact the same thing.”

gestures.plaintext: Why oh my God are thy virtuous creatures ever unhappy! It is because they comprehend nothing of the wonders w’h surround them in the vast vol. of nature—in the divine book of providence w’h nature unfolds, and which revelations writes with sun beams! They grovel in the dark—they feel not after God they perceive not the charm w’h binds the Universe & is diffused over every object & event. Place, objects of sense w’h press on the mind engross them —once animated by the works & government of God—and the enlarged mind sympathising with all that is human—with all that is interesting in the world of ideas & virtue wd defy care ennuie & apathy—the thirst of knowledge kindled—the intellectual eye once opened & tho’ the mind might pant & hunger, yet it’s pains wd be precious & it’s struggles noble.

gestures.plaintext: “In viewing the operations of the Deity, we wer surrounded with infinity of forms, of combination—of magnitudes, of space, of time. The final object of knowlegde is to give us more perfect notions of the supreme Being, & to make us more reciprocally usefull. The degree in w’h we can be usefull, depends in a great measur on the degree according to w’h we can rightly estimate the powers of nature, and according to wh the degree in w’h we know how the Supreme Being adapts the train of causation to the end to be produced. The farther advances we make to the source of all intelligence, we more reason we have to admire his perfections & reverence his power. Admiration must generate the desire of imatation; & serious impressions of religious veneration must give life to a sentiment of universal love & charity.”

               <pb ed="BP" n="6"/></ab> here and the duties & pleasuers of society hereafter. The

                  </abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><expan read="would" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice> be dangerous to collect aro<supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">und</supplied>
               <lb/>me objects of pleasue & amusement in this situation— I <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><abbr>w<hi rend="sup() underline()">d</hi>
                  </abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><expan read="would" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice>
               <lb/>have my heart find no rest on barren ground.</itg>
gestures.plaintext: Were it not that I considered the least ray of knowlegde inconceivably important as producing future effects on my practice & usefullness, I sd not labour thus I sd taste the fuller pleasurs of ease, hope & retirement. I could walk—could knit—could even in this Town find food for my social affections—could amuse myself with books at a high rate, and acquire those showy virtues w’h dazzel & please! But what a dereliction of veiws wd take place! What a different being! My heart wd have objects beneathe it, And tho’ on the whole I might be happier for the present, yet what of old age, when these soothing vertues shall wither! It is a fundamental mistake, fatal to the vitals of an elevated benevolence, that the most social & gentle habits are the surest means of cultivating it’s spirit. It is in hearts subjugated by grace and sanctified from the world, where only the spirit of love is triumphant. True the heart must cultivate by devout sensations the mild & gentle habits of love—they surpass hope, & faith itself —the means alone I dispute, and maintain that as far more promotive of piety is solitude, so is it of the sympathies of benevolence—for these follow that. The fact is, that every process of virtue is a preparation as it relates to the agent and solitude wd be but a dreams of of ease to mortals, were it not preparative to the duties of society here and the duties & pleasuers of society hereafter. The heart ge-nerally preys on something—it wd be dangerous to collect around me objects of pleasue & amusement in this situation— I wd have my heart find no rest on barren ground.

gestures.plaintext: I never was so illy prepared for company & never recevd any so happily nor enjoyed any more In thinking of the omnicience of God we find a rapose & joy equalled by nothing beside. True, it does not prove the actual providence of God in all events— He may govern us by stated laws of in the natural & moral world and interpose neither to resist sin—disease or death. It is certain that were he to act irresistably on the mind there wd appear to be an end of all moral agency & govt . Still, am I disposed off according to laws established or decrees, from eternity I am as resigned & joyfull as if they were this instant formed in the divine mind. Am I left to the precarious & hazardous honors or disgraces w’h may await my own conduct inevitably or probably, it is the wise at moments establishment of a God whom I supremely love—and tho’ I tremble at moments at the present disadvantages w’h may accrue to me from want of commonplac prudence, yet I repose with confidence. God will cause them eventually to work for my good . With a deep & rational conviviction of future scenes, these will require but common courage to surmount. However as a matter of reverent speculation we may conjecture that the infinite Mind in whom we exist & move is never inactive. The human mind seems forever in motion— the material world reposes not an instant, but some of its laws operate with inconceivable velosity—the hand of the Almighty weilds the creation—his eye beholds it—does He only rest!? Yes, in the sublimest sense! his will is the law of nature creation & moves & breathes & thinks & reasons thro’out the Universe!! Lost in wonder & ignorance let us adore & admire & praise Him!! That I love Him supremely I belive b his will & approbation are ultimate

gestures.plaintext: I have been up 13 hours Save 3 I have had them to myself. I wd sacrifice almost any thing to be able to appreciate justly the pleasures & profit of such days. Whether I read the best books I can & whether I read too much I certainly read more than is easy for my eyes or mind—but little very little. I poured over Othello as a literary duty the second time — Ceciro’s letters gave me no animation Neither phislosphy nor grandeur marked the 20 that I looked glanced over Possibly th can be the reason that I find myself asleep over Pliny & Ceciro! Aikins 2 or 3 of those essay may no full. Ran thro’ (for they deserved no more attention) some pages of H— . Unusual ardor in devotion tonight attones for the diap t of knowledge tho’ day. It is painfull that I have made no more advance here—it wd have been natural with such habits. Oh it is important—devout sensations purifys & exalts the soul. A duty to God, inexpressible reverence as well as the warm language of peace & love.

gestures.plaintext: The great Sherlocke goes so far as say the Deity may be affected by prayer somewhat analogous to created beings. But as to the assertion that Butler makes of our “our joys and most of our sufferings being put in our own power” is contradicted by experience & reve— It is the reverse of this truth w’h is a captital difficulty in natural religion—it and to obviate which, seems to be a peculiar advantage in revealed.

gestures.plaintext: In praising God it has a natural tendency to impress the mind with awe of it’s advantages—to realize the distinctions it enjoys—r ed, wittnessed of the Spirit , porting to immortality—called from nothing to be an intelligent part of the Univerce, hold of an existence without a doubt of losing it, whose every law turns on hope! And these last truths are those which are supplied from nature & insured by revelation! Those w’h have their foundation in our moral constitution, and informed by God are very dear to us. But when we contemplate our inability to keep the revealed will of God in any one instance perfectly, and to act up to the dictates of our own reason when our passions are interested, how gratefull we feel, how marvellously gracious appears the interposition of Christ and his attonement! But when we view it in the light of imputation we are bewildered. We are fallen, depraved; deeply by nature. But till the restitution of all things, none will ever know in this life the extent and exact nature of the interposition of Christ. But enough is known for matter of the most constant love gratitude and vigilance. The more exalted and just our views of the duties we owe to God, the more we shall realize our natural inability to discharge them, and the apprehend somthing of the misery attendant on a failure in duty. Lively convictions of truth as it exists in our immortality and our consequent hopes, induce & strenghten a practical faith in Christ and profreessing attachment to his interposition.

               another. We think <lb/>them unhappy, from their situation & emptiness, till we
               <lb/>watch them; and then we conclude it is the mercifull <lb/>arrangement of God
               that they are <hi rend="underline()">full</hi>. <app>
                  <lem>Alass</lem>
                  <rdg wit="#Emerson_MME_Notebooks" wms:loc="RWE2B.289">Also</rdg>
               </app>, it is hap<seg read=" " type="shy-part" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><lb break="no"/>py for them; but let us avoid their destiny, as we
               would <lb/>disgrace. Negative virtue if such it may be called, is dis<seg read=" " type="shy-part" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><lb break="no"/>gracefull to <hi rend="underline()">mind</hi>. <itg type="allusion" xml:id="an179.1259" cert="medium" source="b:IT50043">
                  <hi rend="underline()">What more could I have done</hi>
               </itg>, till <lb/>noon; then <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><abbr>imaja.</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><expan read="imagination" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice> took a quiet possesion. I am not aware <lb/>of my <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><orig>enimeis</orig><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><reg read="enemies" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice>— I maintain no fight— <quote type="misquotation" xml:id="an179.1534" source="b:IT50070">I <hi rend="underline()">return as the</hi>
                  <lb/>
                  <hi rend="underline()">dog to his vomit</hi>
               </quote>. I am a poor needy sinner; complete in <lb/>nothing, lacking in <del>all</del>
               the whole of many things, I <supplied reason="illegible" source="#editors">f</supplied>ear!</itg>
gestures.plaintext: never was a day past in less tho’t—less existence—more ease & glee. The same kind of enjoyment w’h we see bouy up the weake from one period, or desolate, useless life to another. We think them unhappy, from their situation & emptiness, till we watch them; and then we conclude it is the mercifull arrangement of God that they are full. Alass Also , it is happy for them; but let us avoid their destiny, as we would disgrace. Negative virtue if such it may be called, is disgracefull to mind. What more could I have done , till noon; then imaja. took a quiet possesion. I am not aware of my enimeis— I maintain no fight— I return as the dog to his vomit . I am a poor needy sinner; complete in nothing, lacking in all the whole of many things, I fear!

gestures.plaintext: All reasonabe men know that certainly there can not be in reality be such a thing as chance but conclude that such appearances are the result of general laws & must be reduced into them. Tho’ we can trace up the natural causes of things but little way to general law.

gestures.plaintext: There is an influence in society w’h can be accounted for only on metaphysical principles. It is estimable—it is in short, the great bond tho the invisible of society and a sourcee of endless dangers, priviledges, joys & sorrows! We observe not these laws of society till the bitterness of negative & positive experience teach them. How much more forcibly shall we experience these laws in the world of disimbodied spirits! How nameless the importance of our society then! To retrace any particular passage of our lives now dark, or taisteless, or ambiguous in company with some favor-ite spirit, whose long vista of existence has crowned him with distinguished laurels of wisdom & penetration; to trace any of our past journey, and develop it’s character by the aid of this courteous immortal ti how richly repaid for every sufferance. Nor is it unreasonable to conclude that in identifying our past existence we shall at passages blush with modest, not guilty emotions. Yes it may be in such society by their inlightening vision, that we discover the relations of our conduct in such views that those parts w’h have long reproached us shall cease to wound y longer. Would we be distinguished among the endless variety and numbers of the immence community w’h we shall behold, we must cultivate the vertues w’h do not pretend to dazzel and attract the gaze of the world—it must be the rich drapery of humility and love w’h clothes the soul for mansions w’h Jesus prepares. Would we when coasting the riegions of other worlds behold new orders of intelligences with advantages to arrest their attention and invite their interest; let us bear about some peculiar test of our Soverign’s approbation—some rich insignia of his pleasure in us! What does he asign his favorites as instances of his love; the sweet & gentle virtues of the heart, those to w’h he has promised blessedness .

gestures.plaintext: Whatever speculative views people who pretend to philosophise on general priniples say against prayer, we can confute all by the internal evidences of it’s utility. Still reason has her claims. She teaches us that we comprehend scarce any piont of Gods dispensations; that we cannot trace the end of the means nature of cause & effect—the relation in any instance between means and the end, but in matters open to familiar our senses we forget this fact; Whatever effect prayer may have on God—on the, high Priest of our profession who sympathises with our infrimities , it is enough that we are commanded to pray under every dispensation of Gods govt that prayer is uniformly commanded as a duty and enjoined as a d

               to argue against it on the prini<seg read=" " type="shy-part" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><lb break="no"/><seg read=" " type="explicit-whitespace" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><unclear reason="damaged">p</unclear>les of Gods decrees; in those who profess to
               believe the scriptures <lb/>It is enough to silence every objection if God has
               commanded it. <lb/>What it’s nature or tendency farther than to sanctify us we know
               <lb/>not; we perceive <del>not but by</del> and history sacred & prophane records
               <lb/>certain events to follow the prayers <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><abbr>w’h</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><expan read="which" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice> besought them. <itg type="reference" xml:id="an191.1838" source="b:IT50043">The decla<seg read="- " type="shy-part" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><lb break="no"/>ration in Isaiah may well adjust the philosophy and
                  generalise <lb/>the nature of this invisible intercourse with an infinite Being, <lb/>
                  <quote source="b:IT50043"><hi rend="underline()">—before they call I will <del>hear</del> answer, and whilst
                     they are speaking</hi>
                  <lb/>
                  <hi rend="underline()">I will hear</hi></quote>
               </itg> —the answer was prepared in the laws of nature— <lb/>and the request was heard
               from eternity—the events which <lb/>were requested depended on the operations of the
               will of others; <lb/>
               <hi rend="underline()">free</hi>, as well as the exercises of prayer. However, we may
               trace <lb/>this, as any subject in a speculative way, into endless intricacies
               <lb/>and obstruse perplexities. There may be endless disquisitions on the <lb/>nature

               <lb/>for a support from it’s own resources—it takes part with the <lb/>desires of the

If the good <lb/>

                  faculti<supplied reason="illegible" source="#editors">es</supplied>
               <lb/>of the guilty and misirable to implore it’s aid.</itg>
gestures.plaintext: It is an unwarrantable persumption to argue against it on the priniples of Gods decrees; in those who profess to believe the scriptures It is enough to silence every objection if God has commanded it. What it’s nature or tendency farther than to sanctify us we know not; we perceive not but by and history sacred & prophane records certain events to follow the prayers w’h besought them. The declaration in Isaiah may well adjust the philosophy and generalise the nature of this invisible intercourse with an infinite Being, —before they call I will hear answer, and whilst they are speaking I will hear —the answer was prepared in the laws of nature— and the request was heard from eternity—the events which were requested depended on the operations of the will of others; free, as well as the exercises of prayer. However, we may trace this, as any subject in a speculative way, into endless intricacies and obstruse perplexities. There may be endless disquisitions on the nature of food to assimulate with the blood & invisible spirits of the body, and to preseve that active, yet unrecognisable power of life in the constitution of animals; yet instinct irresitably overpowers the difficulties of reason; and reason herself takes a practical part, and the body thrivs. Our nobler instincts prompts to feel often—to adore—to rest upon a power superior to what we behold in visible objects and reason in vain searhc for a support from it’s own resources—it takes part with the desires of the heart and the mind is nourished as actually from this spiritual exercise as the body from imbibing other substances. The above scripture related to the prayers of the good and were matter of promise to times of gospel grace—but such is the native or implied language of the scriptures throout. If the good are to pray, surely the wretched, the weary, the igornt & heavy ladin can have no other resource. Were there only a possibility of a Power superior to nature—a distant hope of be-ing related to it, it would the wisest use of all the faculties of the guilty and misirable to implore it’s aid.

gestures.plaintext: This habit of rising that I have had of late, is mercy itself. How admirably calculated is the state of trial adapted to our constitution—to that unquencable thirst for fame which universally more or less prevails in the human mind. To dirict this to a future good or corrupt its engergies with present objects constitute the man, the philosopher and the xian ! In proportion as it gains strenght in a good diriction every virtue increases. Too strongly it cannot operate as there is not any intimation in the old or new testa. of this life being succeeded by a another of probation. The head of human nature was perfected here— he was made like unto his brethen . His offices and govt remain but no trials. Our bodies and spirits are so wonderfully adapted that it is a dictate of reason to believe their disunion will end the conflicts. To those who aim at high degrees of perfetion, the present variety of dangers and temptations make their state so intense a scene of vigalance that it may well be supposed to equal the longer one of more refined orders of beings whose obedience is attended with no privations! of body or mind!

<itg xmlns="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase" xmlns:wms="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase/manuscript" xmlns:xi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude" type="dialogic_reference" source="b:IT50060 b:IT50048">It is impossible to
               cultivate the peculiar graces of the <lb/>
               <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><abbr>xian</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><expan read="christian" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice> life and gain the approbation of the captivating inhabi<seg read=" " type="shy-part" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><lb break="no"/>tants of a busy world. <quote xml:id="an203.1305" source="b:IT50060">
                  <hi rend="underline()">Ye cannot serve God and mammon!</hi>
               </quote>
               <lb/>Neither can the devotee to praise, however innocent, be per<seg read="- " type="shy-part" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><lb break="no"/>manently happy—the sensibility is tortered, the imajanation be<seg read=" " type="shy-part" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><lb break="no"/>comes micorscopic and represents the evanescent failures of <lb/>the moment as
               barriers to glory. <quote type="misquotation" xml:id="an203.1767" source="b:IT50048">
                  <hi rend="underline()">Seek not honor from men</hi>
                  <lb/>
                  <hi rend="underline()">love not the praise of men more than the praise of God</hi>
               </quote>, must be <lb/>
               <supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">the</supplied> motto of the philosopher in
               contintment as well as the <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><abbr>xian</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><expan read="christian" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice>. <ab type="pbGroup" subtype="add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"><pb ed="HM" n="3b"/>
               <pb ed="GT" n="F1,SVIII" type="continued"/>
               <pb ed="BP" n="16"/></ab> Let the cross, the grave, the crown of <persName>Jesus
                  Christ</persName> regula<supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">te the</supplied>
               <lb/>affection of ambition in every believer of revelation!</itg>
gestures.plaintext: It is impossible to cultivate the peculiar graces of the xian life and gain the approbation of the captivating inhabitants of a busy world. Ye cannot serve God and mammon! Neither can the devotee to praise, however innocent, be permanently happy—the sensibility is tortered, the imajanation becomes micorscopic and represents the evanescent failures of the moment as barriers to glory. Seek not honor from men love not the praise of men more than the praise of God , must be the motto of the philosopher in contintment as well as the xian. Let the cross, the grave, the crown of Jesus Christ regulate the affection of ambition in every believer of revelation!

               & dilligence. I <del>can</del> never can reasonably expect to injoy so <lb/>much
               devotion in any other situation. More <del>active</del>
               <hi rend="underline()">influence</hi> more <lb/>exertion I may injoy—but on the whole
               never more solid & ani<seg read=" " type="shy-part" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><lb break="no"/>mated pleasures. Had I never met various
               trials my virtue migh<supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">t</supplied>
               <lb/>be deceptive. But it is madness to say virtue depends on temp<seg read=" " type="shy-part" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><lb break="no"/>tation & trial for it’s existence. The highest sublimest virtues <lb/>may be
               practised in solitude. <seg xml:id="an207.766"><itg type="paraphrase" source="mb:Edwards_Thoughts" xml:id="f01i009">The heart is the
                     seat of holiness</itg>
                  <lb/>that is never inactivee</seg>. If virtue could only be known and
               <lb/>cultured by the laboures of pity and beneficence, which can <lb/>be practised
               only in a state <del>of</del> where human misery prevails, <lb/>then the highest
               order of beings may not be virtuous.</itg>
gestures.plaintext: I do not expect ever to be happier in this world than I have been for the past months of health & dilligence. I can never can reasonably expect to injoy so much devotion in any other situation. More active influence more exertion I may injoy—but on the whole never more solid & animated pleasures. Had I never met various trials my virtue might be deceptive. But it is madness to say virtue depends on temptation & trial for it’s existence. The highest sublimest virtues may be practised in solitude. The heart is the seat of holiness that is never inactivee. If virtue could only be known and cultured by the laboures of pity and beneficence, which can be practised only in a state of where human misery prevails, then the highest order of beings may not be virtuous.

                     <q rend="underline()">“without”</q> God. &c</itg>

gestures.plaintext: This eve I am disappt of the continua e of my joys by disagreable apprehensions, from these symptoms of my tenia or dropsy, which I often feel without the least apprehension as my health is good. But I never can, I “believe” I never shall suffer a moment’s anxiety, as far as I discern the correcting hand of God. Do what He will his will I shall always love. Greatly have I deserved it’s chastisments; and my own sense of justice will be gratified in my punishment. Pho—as far as I can discern how weake, how cowardly, I was an hour agone! If by stated inevitable laws I suffer, they are Gods laws—whether established a million ages past or this moment, it is the same to me who behold a God continually. If I have ignorantly tampered with them I must submitt. But what we term laws of nature we know but little any m how they operate. It is Gods immediate agency on every particle of matter—not a sparrow “without” God. &c That This method of operation is stated; or & or similar is a mercifull ordination—the basis of all expirience, which is called knowledge In case of what we call miracles the laws of nature are not suspended or reversed—but the mode of acting on mind & matter is different.

               <lb/>can never lose their effect. They are not speculative—they are <lb/>vital
               exercises—where the heart <hi rend="underline()">feels</hi>. And here perhaps I
               <lb/>find the distinction between the growth of virtue in solitude <lb/>&
               sociity. In the latter habits, external<del>ly</del>, increase with more
               <lb/>facility. Innocence is more easily preserved in solitude. But <lb/>it requires
               more strenght & vertue to increase, in solitude, the <lb/>virtues which have no
               assistance from external acts. Habit may <lb/>carry it’s possessor along, in frequent
               cases, somewhat like a ma<seg read="- " type="shy-part" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><lb break="no"/>chine. Clearer virtues <del>demand</del>

gestures.plaintext: Are these passive impressions, such as Butler says weaken on the mind by repitition—whereas habits strenghten the virtuous principle?? No! these tho’ts by often passing the mind can never lose their effect. They are not speculative—they are vital exercises—where the heart feels. And here perhaps I find the distinction between the growth of virtue in solitude & sociity. In the latter habits, externally, increase with more facility. Innocence is more easily preserved in solitude. But it requires more strenght & vertue to increase, in solitude, the virtues which have no assistance from external acts. Habit may carry it’s possessor along, in frequent cases, somewhat like a machine. Clearer virtues demand imply taste, discrimination and the knowledge of the truth of them.

gestures.plaintext: God is mine and I am his! No power short of God himself shall dissuade me from this. As a truth existing in the nature of things it is fast as fate. The heathen had strange notions of fate they said it was uncontroulable by the gods—tho’ they never attributed to it any virtue. It seems they had some ideas w’h are interwoven with the mind of nessisity. God exists by the nessesity of his nature! We adore but with mute reason & reverence. We adore with every faculty of our mind that in Him are is the govt̤ of every agent in nature, matter and mind. Nesissity exists to us but we rejoice it reaches not the operations of the infinite Mind but in connection with the everlasting & immutable attributes which belong to his nature. We rejoice that possesing an emanation from Him, we reason that truth is grafted on our demonstration; we learn that God can not commit contradictions, that there are things w’h he can not do. This nesisity we admit.

                                <hi rend="underline()">I</hi>
                                <lb/>have been weake for many moments. God most holy I
                      <lb/>plead thy promises— I bring the arguments of my misery<seg read=" " type="shy-part" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><lb break="no"/>—do more for me—crushed by exteriors—appear for my
                      <lb/>spirit—if I cannot serve thee—<hi rend="underline()">love thee</hi> and
                      <lb/>fear thee I do not wish for any mode of existence.
                      <lb/>If I cannot glorify thee in life let me die to honor thee
                      <lb/>die and perceive thee—know order & forever & un<seg read="- " type="shy-part" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><lb break="no"/>ceasingly obey it. Perhaps my pride suffers—perhaps
                      <lb/>were I larger these failures would not pain me so—
                      <lb/>While mortal I shall sin— I do not wish to be other
                      <lb/>than human—for then I <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><abbr>s<hi rend="sup() underline()">d</hi></abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><expan read="should" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice> be <app>
                                   <lem>without</lem>
                                   <rdg wit="#Emerson_MME_Notebooks" wms:loc="2B.264">out of</rdg>
                                </app> the pale of <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><abbr>xianity</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><expan read="christianity" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice>
                                <lb/>—blessed province <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><abbr>w’h</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><expan read="which" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice> binds the redeemed nearer the
                    <lb/>throne of the Creator! Perhaps, here Paul <hi rend="underline()">gloried in</hi>
                                <lb/>
                                <hi rend="underline()">infirmity</hi>.</itg>
gestures.plaintext: I have been weake for many moments. God most holy I plead thy promises— I bring the arguments of my misery—do more for me—crushed by exteriors—appear for my spirit—if I cannot serve thee—love thee and fear thee I do not wish for any mode of existence. If I cannot glorify thee in life let me die to honor thee die and perceive thee—know order & forever & unceasingly obey it. Perhaps my pride suffers—perhaps were I larger these failures would not pain me so— While mortal I shall sin— I do not wish to be other than human—for then I sd be without out of the pale of xianity —blessed province w’h binds the redeemed nearer the throne of the Creator! Perhaps, here Paul gloried in infirmity.

gestures.excerpt:
<quote xmlns="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase" xmlns:wms="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase/manuscript" xmlns:xi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude" source="mb:Rollin_Ancient_History" rend="post()" xml:id="f02i002">“Whilst all things
              <lb/>are in motion & fluctuate on the earth; whilst states & empires
              <lb/>pass away with incredible swiftness, & the human race
              <lb/>vainly employed in the external view of these things, are
              <lb/>also drawn in by the same torrent, almost without <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><abbr>percvng</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><expan read="perceiving" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice>
            <lb/>it, there passes in secret an order & disposition of things un<seg read=" " type="shy-part" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><lb break="no"/>known & invisible, <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><abbr>w’h</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><expan read="which" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice>, however, determine our fate to
            <lb/>all eternity. The duration of ages has no other end than
            <lb/>the formation of the bodies of the elect <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><abbr>w’h</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><expan read="which" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice> augments, &
            <lb/>
            <supplied reason="damaged" source="#RollinAncientHistory">ten</supplied>ds daily to perfection. When it shall receive its
            <lb/>
            <supplied reason="damaged" source="#RollinAncientHistory">final</supplied> <supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">accom</supplied>plishment by the death of the last elect</quote>
gestures.plaintext: “Whilst all things are in motion & fluctuate on the earth; whilst states & empires pass away with incredible swiftness, & the human race vainly employed in the external view of these things, are also drawn in by the same torrent, almost without percvng it, there passes in secret an order & disposition of things unknown & invisible, w’h, however, determine our fate to all eternity. The duration of ages has no other end than the formation of the bodies of the elect w’h augments, & tends daily to perfection. When it shall receive its final accomplishment by the death of the last elect

            <lb/>of a God, but by analogy of all human education
            <lb/>they will not acquire gifts different from the
            <lb/>stamina—the constituent principles <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><abbr>w’h</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><expan read="which" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice> compose

            <lb/>stamped for eternity at it’s formation—education
            <lb/>forms—marrs—or perfects them—and supernal
            <lb/>influence directs & sanctifys them. We antiscipate
            <lb/>new powers in eternity—true, but they will
            <lb/>be in unison perhaps to those we exercise now—nay<supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">,</supplied>
            <lb/>
            <supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">th</supplied>e germ—the embreyo of every principle mu<supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">st</supplied>
            <lb/>
            <supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">lie wi</supplied>thin us</itg>
gestures.plaintext: It is to imajanation that faculty of the mind w’h seems to unite the feelings of the heart to the exertions of intellect that are ver the softd tints of past misfortune and the liveliness of future hopes—in fine it is the medium of every joy and harmonises all the soul. As long as idenity exists so long the perogative of a happy imajan will remain: the peculiar gifts, the indefinable combinations of genius will never be the portion of vulgar souls (it seems) even in ages of blessedness! They may grow expatiate and triumph in the devolving wonders of a God, but by analogy of all human education they will not acquire gifts different from the stamina—the constituent principles w’h compose the soul.— the Soul what is it? whatever it be, it’s stamp is given—it’s features are indelibly stamped for eternity at it’s formation—education forms—marrs—or perfects them—and supernal influence directs & sanctifys them. We antiscipate new powers in eternity—true, but they will be in unison perhaps to those we exercise now—nay, the germ—the embreyo of every principle must lie within us

gestures.excerpt:
<quote xmlns="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase" xmlns:wms="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase/manuscript" xmlns:xi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude" source="mb:Burke_Enquiry" xml:id="f02i008">“Before the <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><abbr>xian</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><expan read="christian" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice> religion had as
            <lb/>it were humanised the idea of the Divinity, &
            <lb/>
            <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><abbr>bro’t</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><expan read="brought" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice> it as it were somewhat nearer to us, there
              <lb/>
              <supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">w</supplied>as little said about the love of God. The followers
              <lb/>
              <supplied reason="damaged" source="#Burke_Enquiry">of Plato</supplied> had somthing of it, & only somthing, the othe<supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">r</supplied>
              <lb/>
              <supplied reason="damaged" source="#Burke_Enquiry">writers of</supplied> pagan <supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">an</supplied>tiquity, whether Poets or philosophers,
              <lb/>
              <supplied reason="damaged" source="#Burke_Enquiry">nothing at all. And they who</supplied> <supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">consider</supplied> with <supplied reason="damaged" source="#Burke_Enquiry">what</supplied>
              <ab type="pbGroup" subtype="add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"><pb ed="HM" n="18"/>
              <pb ed="GT" n="F2,S8" type="continued"/>
              <pb ed="BP" n="18"/></ab>
              infinite attention, by what a disregard of i<supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">m</supplied><seg read=" " type="explicit-whitespace" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><lb break="no"/>perishable object, <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><abbr>thro’</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><expan read="through" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice> what long habits of <supplied reason="damaged" source="#Burke_Enquiry">piety</supplied>
              <lb/>& contemplation it is, any man is able to attain <supplied reason="damaged" source="#Burke_Enquiry">an</supplied>
              <lb/>intire love & devotion to the Deity, will easily
              <lb/>perceive that it is not the first, the most
              <lb/>
              <del>striking</del> natural, and the most striking effect
              <lb/>which proceeds from that idea.”</quote>
gestures.plaintext: “Before the xian religion had as it were humanised the idea of the Divinity, & bro’t it as it were somewhat nearer to us, there was little said about the love of God. The followers of Plato had somthing of it, & only somthing, the other writers of pagan antiquity, whether Poets or philosophers, nothing at all. And they who consider with what infinite attention, by what a disregard of imperishable object, thro’ what long habits of piety & contemplation it is, any man is able to attain an intire love & devotion to the Deity, will easily perceive that it is not the first, the most striking natural, and the most striking effect which proceeds from that idea.”

              <lb/>doctrine of <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><abbr>imme.</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><expan read="immateriality" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice> of soul <itg source="mb:NA_Review_of_New_Publications" type="paraphrase">to show that it is phisically & <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><orig>nessesirly</orig><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><reg read="necessarily" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice>
                     <lb/>immortal, but that <hi rend="underline()">it</hi> may refute the objections to its being
          <lb/>able to exist in a seperate state from body.”</itg> 
                  “our knowlegde 
          <lb/>of <hi rend="underline()">nature</hi> of mind too feeble to afford us <hi rend="underline()">positive</hi> 
                     <del>knowlegde</del> argument.
                  <lb/>One evidencee of a future state is <itg source="mb:NA_Review_of_New_Publications" type="paraphrase">the <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><abbr>founda<hi rend="sup()">n</hi>
                        </abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><expan read="foundation" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice> 
                     <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><abbr>w’h</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><expan read="which" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice> 
                     <del>are</del> is laid
          <lb/>in the priciples of our constitution for a progressive &
          <lb/>& unlimited <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><abbr>improv<hi rend="sup()underline()">t</hi>
                        </abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><expan read="improvement" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice></itg>
                   
                   Another is <quote source="mb:NA_Review_of_New_Publications" rend="pre(“)post()">“the natural apprehension
          <lb/>of the mind when under remorse.</quote> On the moral <supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">attri</supplied><seg read=" " type="explicit-whitespace" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><lb break="no"/>butes he calls them benevolence & justice—for the <gap desc="handwriting" reason="damaged"/>
                     <ab type="pbGroup" subtype="add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"><pb ed="HM" n="473"/>
                     <pb ed="GT" n="F41"/>
                     <pb ed="BP" n="2"/>
                     </ab><lb/>he thinks we have a stronge <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><abbr>argu.</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><expan read="argument" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice> 
                     <hi rend="underline()">
                        <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><orig>aprior</orig><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><reg read="apriori" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice>
                     </hi> from the ex<seg read=" " type="shy-part" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><lb break="no"/>quisite pleasure our benivolent acts give us & the appro<seg read="- " type="shy-part" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><lb break="no"/>bation we feel at others beneficence.
               </itg>
gestures.plaintext: D. Stewart says, in his outlines it is not the proper use of the doctrine of imme. of soul to show that it is phisically & nessesirly immortal, but that it may refute the objections to its being able to exist in a seperate state from body.” “our knowlegde of nature of mind too feeble to afford us positive knowlegde argument. One evidencee of a future state is the foundan w’h are is laid in the priciples of our constitution for a progressive & & unlimited improvt Another is “the natural apprehension of the mind when under remorse. On the moral attributes he calls them benevolence & justice—for the he thinks we have a stronge argu. aprior from the exquisite pleasure our benivolent acts give us & the approbation we feel at others beneficence.

                  <lb/>of it— Their being inspired with <hi rend="underline()">languages</hi> did not acquaint

                  <lb/>continus so long as the
        <lb/>reasons on <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><abbr>w’h</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><expan read="which" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice> they were

gestures.plaintext: The obligation of the precepts containd in new tes continus so long as the reasons on w’h they were founded continue, & ceases when the observation of any particular precept is inconsistent with another of a more general nature, or of greater importance for for promoting the essential branches of virtue.

          <lb/>in as general & universal a stile as the precepts of Christ was in some instances
          viola<supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">ted</supplied>

gestures.plaintext: “1. Many precepts are delivered in such manner, as that they must nessecerily admit of some exception, in order to reconcile them with each other, & with the natural law of God, founded on the mutual & immutable relation of things. 2. The law of Moses which is deliverd in as general & universal a stile as the precepts of Christ was in some instances violated without any crime by those who were still in general under the oblgations of that law”

gestures.plaintext: the only “forms” worthy of Plato were those abstracted from matter. Tho’ Bacon says “he lost the advantage of his opinion that forms were the true object of knowledge, by grasping at those which were abstrcd from matter & not as determined in it.” whence he turned to theological opinn & thence infected all his nat. phi. Did he expect to find forms in theology

<quote xmlns="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase" xmlns:wms="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase/manuscript" xmlns:xi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude" xml:id="an45.0" source="mb:Gillies_Aristotles_Ethics">Time an affection of motion
          <lb/>of <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><abbr>w’h</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><expan read="which" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice> God is Author
          <lb/>That kind of life
          <lb/>which the best & happiest
          <lb/>men lead occasionly, in the
          <lb/>unobstructed exercise of their powers
          <lb/>belongs eternally to God in a degree that
          <lb/>should excite admiration in proportion as it
          <lb/>exceeds comprehension.</quote>
gestures.plaintext: Time an affection of motion of w’h God is Author That kind of life which the best & happiest men lead occasionly, in the unobstructed exercise of their powers belongs eternally to God in a degree that should excite admiration in proportion as it exceeds comprehension.

gestures.excerpt:
<itg xmlns="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase" xmlns:wms="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase/manuscript" xmlns:xi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude" type="paraphrase" source="mb:Reid_Inquiry" xml:id="f40i013">“The dissimilitude of our sensations
                  <lb/>& feelings to external things is the innocent Mother of
                  <lb/>those frightfull progeny—that terminates in saying
                  <lb/>that there exists nothing but ideas & impressions—
                  <lb/>that there are no causes nor effects; no substances ma<seg read=" " type="shy-part" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><lb break="no"/>terial or spiritual; no evidencee even in mathematical demon<seg read=" " type="shy-part" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><lb break="no"/>stration; no liberty nor active power; nothing existing in na<seg read=" " type="shy-part" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><lb break="no"/>ture but impressions & ideas following each other with<seg read=" " type="shy-part" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><lb break="no"/>out time or place or subject.” He says too that the ex<seg read=" " type="shy-part" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><lb break="no"/>pectation of the connection of two events is not an <term ref="mt:association">associa<seg read=" " type="shy-part" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><lb break="no"/>tion of ideas</term> but a precsience of mind”</itg>
gestures.plaintext: “The dissimilitude of our sensations & feelings to external things is the innocent Mother of those frightfull progeny—that terminates in saying that there exists nothing but ideas & impressions— that there are no causes nor effects; no substances material or spiritual; no evidencee even in mathematical demonstration; no liberty nor active power; nothing existing in nature but impressions & ideas following each other without time or place or subject.” He says too that the expectation of the connection of two events is not an association of ideas but a precsience of mind”

gestures.excerpt:
<itg xmlns="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase" xmlns:wms="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase/manuscript" xmlns:xi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude" type="paraphrase" source="mb:Reid_Inquiry" xml:id="f40i014">And he calls
            <lb/>this <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><abbr>prn.</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><expan read="principle" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice> not the effect of reasoning but an original priciple
            <lb/>of <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><abbr>hu.</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><expan read="human" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice>
                     <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><abbr>na.</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><expan read="nature" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice>
                     <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><abbr>w’h</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><expan read="which" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice> he calls the <hi rend="underline()">inductive <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><abbr>prin.</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><expan read="principle" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice>
                     </hi> The best models of
          <lb/>inductive reasoning those of <persName ref="mp:SIN1">Newtons</persName>
                     <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><sic>prinipia</sic><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><corr read="principia" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice> & opticks drawn from
            <lb/>
                     <persName ref="mp:FB1">Bacon</persName>. The purpose to show us
            <hi rend="underline()">real</hi> & <hi rend="underline()">apparent</hi> connections of
            <lb/>things in Nature.”</itg>
gestures.plaintext: And he calls this prn. not the effect of reasoning but an original priciple of hu. na. w’h he calls the inductive prin. The best models of inductive reasoning those of Newtons prinipia & opticks drawn from Bacon. The purpose to show us real & apparent connections of things in Nature.”

gestures.excerpt:
<itg xmlns="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase" xmlns:wms="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase/manuscript" xmlns:xi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude" type="intertextual_echo" source="mb:De_Staël_Germany" cert="medium" xml:id="f40i016">That light of the soul—that spark
          <lb/>of glory which will continue to burn on
          <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><abbr>thro’</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><expan read="through" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice> eternity
            <lb/>I mean a stronger portion of feeling—perception—exist<seg read=" " type="shy-part" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><lb break="no"/>ence than belongs to the dull & weake. It is heroism
            <lb/>in the Soldier—self renunciation in the Statsman—self de<seg read=" " type="shy-part" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><lb break="no"/>votion in the Martyr—adoration & fruition of existence
            <lb/>in the Recluse. Oh it is the appetite of hunger in
            <lb/>the soul for knowledge virtue & immotality. That it does
          <lb/>not find fuel enough in this clayey world to feed it</itg>
gestures.plaintext: That light of the soul—that spark of glory which will continue to burn on thro’ eternity I mean a stronger portion of feeling—perception—existence than belongs to the dull & weake. It is heroism in the Soldier—self renunciation in the Statsman—self devotion in the Martyr—adoration & fruition of existence in the Recluse. Oh it is the appetite of hunger in the soul for knowledge virtue & immotality. That it does not find fuel enough in this clayey world to feed it

gestures.excerpt:
<itg xmlns="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase" xmlns:wms="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase/manuscript" xmlns:xi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude" type="paraphrase" source="mb:NA_Review_of_New_Publications" xml:id="f40i019">an ar<seg read="- " type="shy-part" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><lb break="no"/>gument for its’ seprate <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><abbr>exit.</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><expan read="existence" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice> as being independant of matter?
          <lb/>— And if it is not matter it must be spirit as <hi rend="underline()">these</hi> are
          <lb/>all <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><abbr>w’h</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><expan read="which" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice> belong to man, in some of their organisations
          <lb/>But <persName ref="mp:DS2">S.</persName> does not think our knowlege of mind able to af<seg read="- " type="shy-part" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><lb break="no"/>ford us any <hi rend="underline()">positive</hi>
          argument; for we know nothing but
          <lb/>that its’
          <ab type="pbGroup" subtype="add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"><pb ed="GT" n="F38,S568;4"/></ab>
          qualities are essentially different from matter
          <lb/>so is its’ nature.— And he thinks the theory of <persName ref="mp:GB1">Berkly</persName> better
          <lb/>than materialism as the latter only contradicts our <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><sic>perctions</sic><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><corr read="perceptions" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice></itg>
gestures.plaintext: an argument for its’ seprate exit. as being independant of matter? — And if it is not matter it must be spirit as these are all w’h belong to man, in some of their organisations But S. does not think our knowlege of mind able to afford us any positive argument; for we know nothing but that its’ qualities are essentially different from matter so is its’ nature.— And he thinks the theory of Berkly better than materialism as the latter only contradicts our perctions

gestures.excerpt:
<quote xmlns="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase" xmlns:wms="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase/manuscript" xmlns:xi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude" source="mb:NA_Review_of_New_Publications" xml:id="f40i020">There are various circumtances <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><abbr>w’h</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><expan read="which" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice>
                  <del>take place</del> render it
      <lb/>highly probable that the union between soul & body <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><abbr>w’h</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><expan read="which" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice>
                  <lb/>
                  <gap reason="damaged" desc="handwriting"/> takes place in our present state so far from being

                     <lb/>intended to limit the sphere of our information</quote>

gestures.plaintext: The Antients better skilled in morals than phi. accurate study of sci. nesseceery to meta. nothing more unsettled than unconnected than moral code of Antients— Rank & talents often confounded by many of G. phi. love of study & first duties classed togather. In their enthusiasm for faculties of mind, they allowed them a place of esteem beyond every thing else—neglectd heart

gestures.excerpt:
<itg xmlns="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase" xmlns:wms="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase/manuscript" xmlns:xi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude" xml:id="ANN001" type="dialogic_reference distillation" source="mb:Fichte_Destination" cert="medium">Is it in the
                <lb/><supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">n</supplied>ature of things that an
              external <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><abbr>rev.</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><expan read="revelation" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice> should <lb/><supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">t</supplied>hus induce
              faith (more requisite for the <lb/><supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">ab</supplied>solute invalid than for the stake) without it’s <lb/><supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">i</supplied>nternal adaptation to soul—it’s <hi rend="underline()">natural</hi>, like <lb/><supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">th</supplied>e connection betwen cause & effect in <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><orig>phisial</orig><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><reg read="physical" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice>
              <lb/><supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">m</supplied>atters? Were there none of
              this connection <lb/><supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">a</supplied>nd no cause
              existing but the Absolute then <lb/><supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">we</supplied>re we <hi rend="underline()">perhaps</hi> more sure of the infinite
                <lb/><supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">w</supplied>orth of this capasity—gift
              or inspiration! <lb/><seg xml:id="TN005"><supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">If</supplied></seg> so & how antagonist to my very existince is <lb/><supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">th</supplied>e lament of <persName ref="mp:JGF1">Fitche</persName> about his being a mere <lb/><supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">re</supplied>cipient—a spectator—an unwilling agent.</itg>
gestures.plaintext: Is it in the nature of things that an external rev. should thus induce faith (more requisite for the absolute invalid than for the stake) without it’s internal adaptation to soul—it’s natural, like the connection betwen cause & effect in phisial matters? Were there none of this connection and no cause existing but the Absolute then were we perhaps more sure of the infinite worth of this capasity—gift or inspiration! If so & how antagonist to my very existince is the lament of Fitche about his being a mere recipient—a spectator—an unwilling agent.
