<itg xmlns="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase" xmlns:wms="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase/manuscript" xmlns:xi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude" type="dialogic_reference" xml:id="ANN002" source="mb:Plotinus_SelectWorks"><persName ref="mp:P5">Plotinus</persName> says truly <quote type="misquotation" source="mb:Plotinus_SelectWorks">“no one will behold this light
                <lb/><supplied source="#editors" reason="damaged">sp</supplied>eaking of the vision
              of <del>God</del> the supreme, who <lb/><supplied reason="damaged" source="#Plotinus_SelectWorks">is</supplied> drawn downwards by things <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><abbr>w’h</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><expan read="which" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice> are an impedi<lb break="no"/><supplied reason="damaged" source="#Plotinus_SelectWorks">m</supplied>ent to this vision”
            “This One is not absent from
                <lb/><supplied reason="damaged" source="#Plotinus_SelectWorks">a</supplied>ny thing
              and yet is seperated from all things; <lb/><supplied reason="damaged" source="#Plotinus_SelectWorks">so</supplied> that it is present & not present
              with them. <lb/>But it is present with those things that are <lb/><supplied reason="damaged" source="#Plotinus_SelectWorks">a</supplied>ble & prepared to
              recive it so that they be-<lb break="no"/><supplied reason="damaged" source="#Plotinus_SelectWorks">co</supplied>me congruous & as it were pass into
              contact <lb/><supplied reason="damaged" source="#Plotinus_SelectWorks">w</supplied>ith
              it <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><abbr>thro’</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><expan read="through" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice> similitude & a certain inherent <lb/><supplied reason="damaged" source="#Plotinus_SelectWorks">p</supplied>ower allied to that <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><abbr>w’h</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><expan read="which" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice> is imparted by the one.”</quote>
            <lb/><supplied reason="damaged" source="#Plotinus_SelectWorks">H</supplied>ere is
            genuine truth of reason & coeval with <lb/>the latest <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><abbr>rev.</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><expan read="revelation" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice>! Dear sainted <persName ref="mp:P5">Plotinus</persName>! <quote source="mb:Plotinus_SelectWorks">“God is not in <lb/><supplied reason="damaged" source="#Plotinus_SelectWorks">a</supplied> certain place so as to
              desert other things; but wherever <lb/><supplied reason="damaged" source="#Plotinus_SelectWorks">a</supplied>ny thing is able to come in contact with
              Him there <lb/><gap desc="handwriting" reason="damaged"/>
              <del>not</del> He is present.”</quote>. <quote source="mb:Plotinus_SelectWorks">“Cause howevr is not the same
                <lb/><supplied reason="damaged" source="#Plotinus_SelectWorks">w</supplied>ith the
              thing caused.”</quote>
            <quote source="mb:Plotinus_SelectWorks">Hence must it not
              be denom<lb break="no"/><supplied reason="damaged" source="#Plotinus_SelectWorks">in</supplied>ated that good <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><abbr>w’h</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><expan read="which" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice> it imparts to others; but it is <lb/><supplied reason="damaged" source="#Plotinus_SelectWorks">an</supplied>other manner <hi rend="underline()">the
                good</hi>, in a way transcending other <lb/><supplied reason="damaged" source="#Plotinus_SelectWorks">go</supplied>ods.”</quote>— <del>I”</del> — — <itg type="paraphrase" source="mb:Plotinus_SelectWorks">If the soul wishes to
              abide on high she <lb/><supplied reason="damaged" source="#Plotinus_SelectWorks">wi</supplied>ll consider <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><orig>potitical</orig><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><reg read="political" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice> concerns <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><orig>unwothy</orig><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><reg read="unworthy" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice> to be the sub<lb break="no"/><supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">jec</supplied>ts of conference with the Deity. For this will be hi<supplied reason="illegible" source="#editors">s</supplied>
              <lb/><supplied reason="damaged" source="#Plotinus_SelectWorks">lang</supplied>uage who
                  has seen much of divinity. <quote source="mb:Plotinus_SelectWorks"><hi rend="underline()">For as it is</hi>
              <lb/><supplied reason="damaged" source="#Plotinus_SelectWorks">said</supplied>, <hi rend="underline()">God is not external to any one but is present</hi>
              <lb/><supplied reason="damaged" source="#Plotinus_SelectWorks">with</supplied>
              <hi rend="underline()">all things, <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><abbr>tho’</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><expan read="though" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice> they are ignorant that he is so</hi>
              <lb/><supplied reason="damaged" source="#Plotinus_SelectWorks">for</supplied> they fly
              from Him, rather from themselves.”</quote></itg></itg>
gestures.plaintext: Plotinus says truly “no one will behold this light speaking of the vision of God the supreme, who is drawn downwards by things w’h are an impediment to this vision” “This One is not absent from any thing and yet is seperated from all things; so that it is present & not present with them. But it is present with those things that are able & prepared to recive it so that they be-come congruous & as it were pass into contact with it thro’ similitude & a certain inherent power allied to that w’h is imparted by the one.” Here is genuine truth of reason & coeval with the latest rev.! Dear sainted Plotinus! “God is not in a certain place so as to desert other things; but wherever any thing is able to come in contact with Him there not He is present.”. “Cause howevr is not the same with the thing caused.” Hence must it not be denominated that good w’h it imparts to others; but it is another manner the good, in a way transcending other goods.”— I” — — If the soul wishes to abide on high she will consider potitical concerns unwothy to be the subjects of conference with the Deity. For this will be his language who has seen much of divinity. For as it is said, God is not external to any one but is present with all things, tho’ they are ignorant that he is so for they fly from Him, rather from themselves.”

gestures.plaintext: Chap. on the One. Plotinus reminds of w’h the artist says are in the quarry. Revelation have discovered a nobler decided faith & appre-hensions) of the Divinity than the highest tho’t of artist ever gave to the Statue w’h had been laboured into form of more than mortal beauty. What clouds & shawdows bedim that bright Spirit when labouring to produce into form the simpleist & grandest ideas of God—ideas & elements w’h constitute a soul! And w’h when developed by foreign aid become so united to prac-tical and intuitive reason.

gestures.plaintext: 14 sab Eve And yet when he de-scribes the nature & affinities of soul how may the xian be put a back who hesitates whether it is immediately consious after death. One would almost wish they had nver heard of the resurrec-tion of body, & tho wholly indifferent to its rising yet so mingled are the duties—so wholly the xian dis-cipline seems to depend on it with the obscure truth we can’t separate it easily.

            <lb/>almost wish they had nver heard of the resur<supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">rec-</supplied><seg read=" " type="explicit-whitespace" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><lb break="no"/>tion of body, & <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><abbr>tho</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><expan read="though" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice> wholly indifferent to its rising y<supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">et</supplied>
            <lb/>so mingled are the duties—so wholly the <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><abbr>xian</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><expan read="christian" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice>
            <supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">dis-</supplied><seg read=" " type="explicit-whitespace" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><lb break="no"/>cipline seems to depend on it with the obscure <supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">truth</supplied>
            <lb/>we can’t separate it easily.</itg>
gestures.plaintext: And yet when he de-scribes the nature & affinities of soul how may the xian be put a back who hesitates whether it is immediately consious after death. One would almost wish they had nver heard of the resurrec-tion of body, & tho wholly indifferent to its rising yet so mingled are the duties—so wholly the xian dis-cipline seems to depend on it with the obscure truth we can’t separate it easily.

<quote xmlns="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase" xmlns:wms="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase/manuscript" xmlns:xi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude" source="mb:Plotinus_SelectWorks" xml:id="ANN005">“Hence it <supplied reason="damaged" source="#Plotinus_SelectWorks">is</supplied>
            <lb/>nessecay to hasten<del>d</del> our departure from hence <supplied reason="damaged" source="#Plotinus_SelectWorks">to</supplied>
            <lb/>be indignant that we are bound to one par<supplied reason="damaged" source="#Plotinus_SelectWorks">t of</supplied>
            <lb/>our nature, in order that with the whole of our <supplied reason="damaged" source="#Plotinus_SelectWorks">true</supplied>
            <lb/>selves <del>may</del> we may fold oursleves about divi<supplied reason="damaged" source="#Plotinus_SelectWorks">nity</supplied>
            <lb/>& have no part void of contact with him! W<supplied reason="damaged" source="#Plotinus_SelectWorks">hen</supplied>
          <lb/>this takes place therefore<supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">,</supplied> the
            soul <supplied reason="damaged" source="#Plotinus_SelectWorks">will both see <lb/>divinity
              and herself, as far as it is lawful for her to see him.</supplied></quote>
gestures.plaintext: “Hence it is nessecay to hastend our departure from hence to be indignant that we are bound to one part of our nature, in order that with the whole of our true selves may we may fold oursleves about divinity & have no part void of contact with him! When this takes place therefore, the soul will both see divinity and herself, as far as it is lawful for her to see him.

gestures.plaintext: And how clearly does Plotinus reprsent the state (w’h cannot be explained,) of the vision—or extacy expansion & accession or going out of one’s self” the prohets!! even the princly Isaiah or herd of xians! “If howver he has entered the Adytum he obtains a true vision—if not entered, he will conceiv this Adytum to be a certain invisible thing, & will have a knowledge of the fountain & priciple of things. But when situated there, he will see the principle, & be conjoined with it, by a union of like with like, neglecting nothing divine w’h the soul is able to possess.” “Prior to the vision also it requirs that w’h remains from the vision. But that w’h remains to him who passes beyond all things is that w’h is prior to all things. For the nature of the soul will never accede to that w’h is intirely non being. But proceeding indeed downwards it falls into evil & thus into non being, yet not that w’h is perfect non entity. Running, howevr, in a contrary deriction it arises not at another thing, but at itself. To be in itself alone, and not in being, is to be in God. For God is somthing w’h is not essence but beyond essence. Hence the soul when in this condition associa-tes with Him. — — — — And if he passes from himself as an image to the Archetype, he will then have the end of his progression. But when he falls from the vision of God, if he from the vision, if he again excites the vir-tue w’h is in himself, & percies himself to be perfectly adorned; he will again be ele-vated thro’ vitue, proceeding to intellet & wis-dom, & afterwards to the priciple of all things.” Alas, had the soul not arived to this Priciple

                a</supplied> contrary <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><orig>deriction</orig><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><reg read="direction" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice> it arises not at another <lb/><supplied reason="damaged" source="#Plotinus_SelectWorks">thi</supplied>ng, but at itself. <hi rend="underline()">To be in itself alone</hi>, <hi rend="underline()">and</hi>
              <lb/><supplied reason="damaged" source="#Plotinus_SelectWorks">no</supplied><hi rend="underline()">t in being, is to be in God</hi>. For God is som<lb break="no"/><supplied reason="damaged" source="#Plotinus_SelectWorks">thi</supplied>ng <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><abbr>w’h</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><expan read="which" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice> is not essence but beyond essence. <lb/><supplied reason="damaged" source="#Plotinus_SelectWorks">Hen</supplied>ce the soul when in this condition
                associa-<lb break="no"/><supplied reason="damaged" source="#Plotinus_SelectWorks">tes</supplied> with Him. — — — — And if he passes from him<lb break="no"/><supplied reason="damaged" source="#Plotinus_SelectWorks">self</supplied> as an
              image to the Archetype, he will <lb/><supplied reason="damaged" source="#Plotinus_SelectWorks">then h</supplied>ave the end of his progression. But
                <lb/><supplied reason="damaged" source="#Plotinus_SelectWorks">when he falls
                from</supplied> the vision of God, i<supplied source="#editors" reason="damaged">f</supplied> he <lb/><gap desc="handwriting" reason="damaged"/>
              <ab type="pbGroup" subtype="add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"><pb ed="HM" n="406b"/>
              <pb ed="GT" n="F24"/>
              <pb ed="BP" n="6"/>
              <pb ed="BP-alt" n="5"/>
              </ab><lb/>from the vision, if he again excites <supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">the
                vir-</supplied><seg read=" " type="explicit-whitespace" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><lb break="no"/>tue <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><abbr>w’h</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><expan read="which" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice> is in himself, & <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><orig>percies</orig><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><reg read="perceives" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice> himself <supplied reason="damaged" source="#Plotinus_SelectWorks">to</supplied>
              <lb/>be perfectly adorned; he will again be e<supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">le-</supplied><seg read=" " type="explicit-whitespace" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><lb break="no"/>vated <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><abbr>thro’</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><expan read="through" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice>
              <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><orig>vitue</orig><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><reg read="virtue" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice>, proceeding to <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><orig>intellet</orig><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><reg read="intellect" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice> & w<supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">is-</supplied><seg read=" " type="explicit-whitespace" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><lb break="no"/>dom, & afterwards to the priciple of all thi<supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">ngs.”</supplied></quote>
gestures.plaintext: “If howver he has entered the Adytum he obtains a true vision—if not entered, he will conceiv this Adytum to be a certain invisible thing, & will have a knowledge of the fountain & priciple of things. But when situated there, he will see the principle, & be conjoined with it, by a union of like with like, neglecting nothing divine w’h the soul is able to possess.” “Prior to the vision also it requirs that w’h remains from the vision. But that w’h remains to him who passes beyond all things is that w’h is prior to all things. For the nature of the soul will never accede to that w’h is intirely non being. But proceeding indeed downwards it falls into evil & thus into non being, yet not that w’h is perfect non entity. Running, howevr, in a contrary deriction it arises not at another thing, but at itself. To be in itself alone, and not in being, is to be in God. For God is somthing w’h is not essence but beyond essence. Hence the soul when in this condition associa-tes with Him. — — — — And if he passes from himself as an image to the Archetype, he will then have the end of his progression. But when he falls from the vision of God, if he from the vision, if he again excites the vir-tue w’h is in himself, & percies himself to be perfectly adorned; he will again be ele-vated thro’ vitue, proceeding to intellet & wis-dom, & afterwards to the priciple of all things.”

gestures.plaintext: And when absorbed in the open-ing sights of original Divinity—oh dare I antisipate—so unworthy—so fallen from youthfell good by carelessness—more from that “forgetfullness of all that justice might have required of affection how dare I long as formerly to plunge into the abyss of the Infinite—to lose all but consciousness of that! And yet I would not lose those thoughts & feelings w’h thro life have united me to the One—when to be alone forever thus so dear

gestures.plaintext: And what cognisences of God dwelt in these men, their life partakes of Deiety how below the xian trintity— yet respected. And how destinct their intuition of the One till they smothered it by theories. I the chap. on “immotality of Soul” would shame the best of the materialists by the strenght of its arguments on its indivisible real nature? Alas! it seemed that mine was divisible much of the time to all skey & earthly influences. And when the moments of concentration is given it seems to idealise the eternal “nows” of time of my noble author. If a cloud or tree seemd a part of me this morning—’twas but as a lar On time—they are confused when calling it the same with eternity—why not rest there—for it is only named & parceled out by planets and the sad history of man, who has made of it a god—& sacrifices body & soul to its molock claims. Time as an abstract idea was always—oh tre-mendous time what hast thou numbered since the fleeting race have given thee But hear the Sage “It is requisite that we should betake ourselves to that condition of being w’h we say is in eternity; a condition w’h is im-mutable, & at once total, a life now infinite and perfectly flexible and abiding in one, and directed to the One”. He gose on to speake of time “generated by the reason & nature of that w’h is posterior.”

            He <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><orig>gose</orig><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><reg read="goes" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice> on to speake of <lb/>time “generated by the reason & nature of
              tha<supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">t</supplied>
            <lb/><choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><abbr>w’h</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><expan read="which" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice> is posterior.”</itg>
gestures.plaintext: why not rest there—for it is only named & parceled out by planets and the sad history of man, who has made of it a god—& sacrifices body & soul to its molock claims. Time as an abstract idea was always—oh tre-mendous time what hast thou numbered since the fleeting race have given thee But hear the Sage “It is requisite that we should betake ourselves to that condition of being w’h we say is in eternity; a condition w’h is im-mutable, & at once total, a life now infinite and perfectly flexible and abiding in one, and directed to the One”. He gose on to speake of time “generated by the reason & nature of that w’h is posterior.”

But hear him on clearer ground.</itg> <quote source="mb:Plotinus_SelectWorks">“Wh<supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">o-</supplied><seg read=" " type="explicit-whitespace" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><lb break="no"/>ever fancies that beings governed by chanc<supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">e or</supplied>

gestures.plaintext: “Time an image of eternity” in the stillness of the “wilderness where God hath built,” at mid-night it thus becomes, undefiled—unstunned and we cannot say with the philosopher “that the Demiurgus made day & night to apprehend two things— — —from w’h Plato said they arived at the conception of number” They might—but night & day too was made for nobler—infinite pur-poses! But hear him on clearer ground. “Who-ever fancies that beings governed by chance or fortune & are held togather by corporeal causes is very remote from God & conception of the One

gestures.plaintext: Thou art more—as one of my antients say—“a proceeding intellect, established indeed in eternity but proceeding & abundantly flowing int the things w’h are gaurded by it” But more grand grand & clear is time streching his immeasurble tremendous wings thro’ the fathomless past & future by being “the mode of Gods existence the existence of duration.” Rather may we pass to the venerable Clarke & say it is the very life of God that constitues time & splace!

gestures.plaintext: Glorious—tell us not dear & venerable Clark that virtue (in nature & origin) does not originate crated in creatures in His will —it is the eternal fittness—to w’h it is our eter optimism to conform—utility for immutable perfection—“sympathy” with the origian of morals—not debased forms of it in man. If Waldo had given? his spiritual wrld this will I should better have understood the inlargment of ours to it as the source of the moral.

gestures.plaintext: Why was thy veneable head so misled by the natural conclusions of Spinozaism—puts all of poor imprisoned cratures in a govt free & material. But were there but “one Substance relative & extensive infinitly.” & every thing modifications of it”—the old forgery, of the bible God, would still hope to be a modification of joy & hope—he would at the sight of sin & misery say this modification is a nessecay evil?— —but does not impeach the infinite bene-volence of the Being who is united by nesesity to the destiny of univesal society. True, there is neither reason nor sense here but feeling. Ah how impossible to demonstrate by reasonings what “pretumuous reason” feels. But against nesseity in bad senses of Spinozaism, the indilible characters on the soul are the sure demonstrations—these triumph over all the plausibilietites of heretics in nat. or rev. theology—philosophy & science. Oppose it with themselves they become mere phenomena

            faith (more requisite for the <lb/><supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">ab</supplied>solute invalid than for the stake) without it’s <lb/><supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">i</supplied>nternal adaptation to soul—it’s <hi rend="underline()">natural</hi>, like <lb/><supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">th</supplied>e connection betwen cause & effect in <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><orig>phisial</orig><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><reg read="physical" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice>
            <lb/><supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">m</supplied>atters? Were there none of this
            connection <lb/><supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">a</supplied>nd no cause existing
            but the Absolute then <lb/><supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">we</supplied>re we
              <hi rend="underline()">perhaps</hi> more sure of the infinite <lb/><supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">w</supplied>orth of this capasity—gift or inspiration!
              <lb/><seg xml:id="TN005"><supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">If</supplied></seg>
            so & how antagonist to my very existince is <lb/><supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">th</supplied>e lament of <persName ref="mp:JGF1">Fitche</persName> about his
            being a mere <lb/><supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">re</supplied>cipient—a
            spectator—an unwilling agent.</itg>
gestures.plaintext: Is it in the nature of things that an external rev. should thus induce faith (more requisite for the absolute invalid than for the stake) without it’s internal adaptation to soul—it’s natural, like the connection betwen cause & effect in phisial matters? Were there none of this connection and no cause existing but the Absolute then were we perhaps more sure of the infinite worth of this capasity—gift or inspiration! If so & how antagonist to my very existince is the lament of Fitche about his being a mere recipient—a spectator—an unwilling agent.

          <date when="1834-04-18">April 18<hi rend="sup()">th</hi> 1834—</date>
          <ab><lb break="no"/>“Go thy ways Day— Many eyes now rest on thee—thou art <supplied reason="damaged" source="mb:EmersonCC_41834">of</supplied>
            <lb/>consequence to the thousands of them who wait with fear <lb/>or hope the issue of
            what has been done in thee—& thou <lb/>art remembered as a benefactor or an enemy by
            those to <lb/>whom thou hast brought joy or disaster in thy brief reign. <lb/>But as the
            moon wanes from the full—as the mountain<del>s</del> lessen <lb/>when we retreat from it
            till its blue top sinks beneath <lb/>the horizon—even so will thy dimensions shrink as
            the long <lb/>procession of coming Days shall glide by & take station in <lb/>front
            of thee. Thy coat of many colours will be
              stripped of<supplied reason="damaged" source="mb:EmersonCC_41834">f</supplied><supplied reason="damaged" source="#editors">,</supplied>
            <lb/>& thou shalt be clad in the faint grey livery of things dis<seg read="- " type="shy-part" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><lb break="no"/>tant & cold.”</ab>
        </quote>
gestures.plaintext: April 18th 1834— “Go thy ways Day— Many eyes now rest on thee—thou art of consequence to the thousands of them who wait with fear or hope the issue of what has been done in thee—& thou art remembered as a benefactor or an enemy by those to whom thou hast brought joy or disaster in thy brief reign. But as the moon wanes from the full—as the mountains lessen when we retreat from it till its blue top sinks beneath the horizon—even so will thy dimensions shrink as the long procession of coming Days shall glide by & take station in front of thee. Thy coat of many colours will be stripped off, & thou shalt be clad in the faint grey livery of things distant & cold.”

            with thy record that cannot be amen<seg read="- " type="shy-part" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><lb break="no"/><supplied reason="damaged" source="mb:EmersonCC_201133">d</supplied>ed into the <seg xml:id="TN007">Eternity</seg> whither I too shall soon follow thee— <lb/>If thou art questioned by

gestures.plaintext: Nov 20 1833 Day, Day, that art even now taking thy farewell—hastening over my head into the shadowy Infinite Past— I know not whether I ought to be grieved as I listen to the rush of thy retreating wings— True I have learned nothing that Can be weighed or measured by the coarse scales of human opinion since my eyes opened on thy light. I confess a heavy & indolent morning—an unthoughtful afternoon. But if the soul has simply kept or put herself —in the attitude of a humble seeker of truth, thy golden sands have not been wasted. Galileo was long making & adjusting his telescope, before it disclosed to him the wonders of the heavenly world. And much of every man’s life is spent in preparation indirect, often unconscious, for duties & achievements to come. Go then with thy record that cannot be amended into the Eternity whither I too shall soon follow thee— If thou art questioned by my Guardian Angel, say thou didst leave me strong in the spirit of prayer & hope.”

gestures.excerpt:
<quote xmlns="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase" xmlns:wms="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase/manuscript" xmlns:xi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude" source="mb:NA_Art1_CharlesElwood" xml:id="ANN003">“The highest virtue
          consists in the fact that the <lb/><supplied reason="damaged" source="mb:NA_Art1_CharlesElwood">s</supplied>oul is in such a state that it’s natural aspira<seg read="- " type="shy-part" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><lb break="no"/><supplied reason="damaged" source="mb:NA_Art1_CharlesElwood">t</supplied>ions, it’s spontaneous emotions, are in
          harmony <lb/><supplied reason="damaged" source="mb:NA_Art1_CharlesElwood">w</supplied>ith the will of God; so
          that it obeys God without <lb/><supplied reason="damaged" source="mb:NA_Art1_CharlesElwood">de</supplied>liberation, without reflection, from it’s own natural <lb/><supplied reason="damaged" source="mb:NA_Art1_CharlesElwood">p</supplied>romptings. It is then
          sanctified”</quote>
gestures.plaintext: “The highest virtue consists in the fact that the soul is in such a state that it’s natural aspirations, it’s spontaneous emotions, are in harmony with the will of God; so that it obeys God without deliberation, without reflection, from it’s own natural promptings. It is then sanctified”

Where would be

gestures.plaintext: This morning I read a “few sentences of the certainty of morality! I used to choose that the will of God (whom I love) should be the fountain & origin of all morality— But my ideas have alwys been confused—as led to faith & piety before the theory of morals. But could it not exist in the eternal and have no relation or obligation to man were man only a body without any attributes of spirit. Where would be the what is falsly called the moral sense —where any congruity between the eternal obligations of right conduct and a creature without any principles inherent, w’h are adopted to morality? All application of religion must thus be miraculous.

<itg xmlns="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase" xmlns:wms="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase/manuscript" xmlns:xi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude" type="reference" guessture="dialogic-reference" xml:id="ANN015" source="mb:Butler_Analogy">It is well to be ware of the delu<seg read="- " type="shy-part" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><lb break="no"/>sion of <hi rend="underline()">feelings</hi>—what are called <hi rend="underline()">frames</hi>— And in every <lb/>ssubject there <hi rend="underline()">may</hi> be delusion. In the speculations of the most
                  <lb/>prolific brain on the deepest, are often errors of immense <lb/>size, obvious
                  to the <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><orig>plainst</orig><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><reg read="plainest" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/></choice> sense— In every science, in every <lb/>department of philosophy, save
                  experimental (poor sensible <lb/>manual experiment) there has been found

Why not <hi rend="underline()">in feeling</hi>? gestures.plaintext: It is well to be ware of the delusion of feelings—what are called frames— And in every ssubject there may be delusion. In the speculations of the most prolific brain on the deepest, are often errors of immense size, obvious to the plainst sense— In every science, in every department of philosophy, save experimental (poor sensible manual experiment) there has been found deceptions & errors from the wildest to the most desipacable kind. Then where is certainty and what are its surest limits? Why not in feeling? We all know whither we are at ease, whether suffering the nameless pangs of restlessness, ill humour and dreaded apathy, or tasting the indiscrible joys of sympathy, benvolence & activity. Here is experiment in the very essence of the soul & surerr than those of matter—for some say, there is no body. In consciousness there can be no delusion, even where no body nor & spirit in the world. And when concsious of the perfections of God, without raticiconation, the joy is certain & infablible—so of every other sentiment which inraptures & ennobles. If Butler meant these feelings, when he said somthing (I almost forget) about weakening the priciples of action, then I wont believe him, tho’ I seldom pass a week without trembling at his verdict—without desiring to do, to act, without the aid of feeling. And mayhap the purest virtue is independent. But of what nature is vertue without consciousness of it? Does the Martyr, the Reformer the Missionary act without feeling a stronge persusion of the truth for w’h he suffers. Does he go thro’ incalculable sufferings guided only the cool dedutions of reason & the connection of truth? Probably Butler meant the proscription of feelings w’h only swims in the fancy—never warm the affections nor subdue the passions

                  <persName ref="mp:ML1">Luther’s</persName> life. What an eternal wittness of the
                  agency of God <lb/>with that of man! His sorrows misgivings & concessions
                  <lb/>to Rome discover the natural workings of man. His <lb/>daring courage, his
                  miraculous faith (without the <hi rend="underline()">show</hi>
                  <lb/>of miricle) bespeake the agency of God without a doubt. <lb/>How much richer
                  a gift, how much more adapted to the <lb/>condition of man was the reformation by
                  apparent (and in <lb/>some reality) by human methods than by miricle! The for<seg read="- " type="shy-part" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.13"/><lb break="no"/>mation of <persName ref="mp:ML1">Luther’s</persName> mind was ordained
                  by God as a means of <lb/>it, yet how many causes natural & coporeal were in
                  the <lb/>chain!</itg>
gestures.plaintext: I have been reading or rather poring over Luther’s life. What an eternal wittness of the agency of God with that of man! His sorrows misgivings & concessions to Rome discover the natural workings of man. His daring courage, his miraculous faith (without the show of miricle) bespeake the agency of God without a doubt. How much richer a gift, how much more adapted to the condition of man was the reformation by apparent (and in some reality) by human methods than by miricle! The formation of Luther’s mind was ordained by God as a means of it, yet how many causes natural & coporeal were in the chain!
